content: My original design was a real moebius strip but the coordinated work with CG finally came out as a "deformed" moebius strip, with crossable edge. It is not fully align with my preference but at this stage I'm afraid I could not edit it very much.
It's not a moebius strip! Please fix that, the confusion the wrong description causes is really annoying.

The description of puzzle is different from the one in contest. 
[Puzzle] Printing, folding and gluing horizontally the data strip is not the same as
[Contest] Printing left data half, flipping vertically and printing right half.
The solution from the contest works and animation behaves according to the contests, however based on the changed description it shouldn't for the puzzle.

It is another way to modalize the mobius strip.

As many people feel confused with the description in the contest. I tried to explain the topology in an improved way together with a diagram showing the procedure.

I assure two results from the two descriptions have the same topology and the solution fits both descriptions.

Let's skip the twisting part cause it's the same for both approaches and try to get double-sided strip.
Imagine the follwing 2x4 data:
A##B
##C#

[Contest]
Print the first half (along the x-axis) of the grid on a piece of paper.
Flip the paper over vertically. (This is the crucial part, doing VERTICAL (not horizontal flip) will never give the same topology)
Print the rest of the grid on the side now in front of you.

[Puzzle]
Print the data on a (long enough) piece of paper. Trim the borders.
Fold the paper horizontally, evenly dividing the data. Glue the paper back-to-back so that it becomes a strip with double-sided data.

Now with both these double-sided strips let's try to go over the edge ^ from A:
- According to Contest description going up from A you will end up in C ^;
- Based on Puzzle description going from A ^ will get you to B v. (see the folding on the image https://imgur.com/6ps3GBG)

Please let me know where is my understanding wrong? 
With HORIZONTAL flip you get the same topology but with VERTICAL you don't.

No matter you use the horizontal or vertical folding/flipping method,
if you give it a twist and connect the ends, A is connected to both B and C, and the direction change (or unchange) is the same.
In terms of topology, they are they same.

It does matter. Print left half and do HORIZONTAL flip (from left to right) to print right half is in fact equivalent to folding technique -> it doesn't change top and bottom. However print left half and flip VERTICAL (from top to bottom) to print right half changes top and bottom resulting in a different topology. Please hear me out and at least try the small example I put in previous comment. 
I would also like to invite reviewers in out discussion to judge eulerscheZahl, MadKnight, pac-nam
That's perfectly fine. You could msg euler who seems to be often online.

Hi Geo, after a second thought, I think you have your point. I conclude that the two descriptions still result in the same topology not affecting the validity of the programming result, but the looping effect in the viewer reflects the older description. I am deciding to update the description and diagram. Thanks your input.
One more proof of difference in topologies. Please check two short .gif videos I made: https://imgur.com/a/CRwizOI

Seems I'm late to the party, GeoConHD contacted me in the chat.
I fully agree with GeoConHD: the resulting MÃ¶bius strip is different to the one obtained in the contest. It maps different fields to each other at the edge.

When I approved, I checked that the viewer isn't broken and my contest solution still passes.
I didn't realize that the description of the topology changed, which I'm really sorry for.
Thanks for bringing this up, GeoConHD.

Update done. 
The main reason to change is to fit description with the viewer. In the design stage we discussed various ways to present the data and description. Different people tried following different descriptions to write their solutions and finally everyone's results are the same. So i belief the topology does not change. The description now is following the viewer's direction to go. Hope you like it.
